<u>CONFIDENTIAL.
<\u>

REFEREE'S REPORT.

To the Sectional Committee for Mathematics
Paper by R.A.Fisher,
On The Mathematical Foundations of Theoretical 
Statistics.
1. Whether the paper should be read before the Society. 
Yes.
2. Whether the paper should or should not be published by the Society. 
Yes.
3. Whether, in the former case, it should be published in the "Philosophical Transactions" 
or the "Proceedings." (See Standing Orders on opposite page.) 
Transactions.
4. Whether it should be published in full or only in part, or whether any material modifications 
are necessary. 
In full 
5. Which illustrations, if any, accompanying the paper should be reproduced
All. (I do not quite understand the "guide for reproduction 
of other diagrams - what is to be done with it.) 
General Remarks.
The paper shows a remarkable insight into the theoretical ideas 
on which the methods of statistics ought to be based. I do not think that 
anyone else has arrived at so clear-sighted a view. The illustrative examples, 
and the application of the theoretical developments to a criticism of methods 
employed in practice are excellent; the criticism is fair, and shows the merits 
as well as the defects of previous work. It is an excellent paper, and I have 
no hesitation in recommending that it be printed as it stands (The Secretaries 
might, however, look at the notation in case some of the signs [symbol], [symbol], etc. are 
impracticable for the printers.)
